results.title: The Tempest in Bali
results.creator_credit: SBS-TV, Ugo Mariotti and Barbara Mariotti
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Australian mosaic”.
In 1988 a group of students from Murdoch University under the leadership of David George and Serge Tampalini staged a production of Shakespeare’s “The Tempest” in Bali during the monsoon. The program documents the various bureaucratic problems they encountered and the assimilation of Balinese dance, music and shadow puppets into the production.

results.title: Errol Flynn
results.creator_credit: Film Australia, Ron Saunders, Pamela Vanneck and Michael Carson
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Willesee’s Australians”.
This moving drama series on important figures from Australia’s past brings Australian history to life. Errol Flynn’s natural charm and good looks saw him become a screen legend as Hollywood’s greatest swashbuckling lover and matinee idol. This film takes an irreverent look at the nineteen year old Flynn’s escapades in Sydney as he sets off on the path to notoriety.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Film Australia, Ron Saunders, Pamela Vanneck and Michael Carson

results.title: [Remix: Transport]
results.brief_description: This short film is a remix of archival footage from the ACMI Collection, focusing on public transport in Victoria. The remix contains footage of trams, trains, Flinders Street Station and city streets in Melbourne.

results.title: Roots of happiness
results.creator_credit: Sun Dial Films, Puerto Rico. Dept. of Health and Henwar Rodakiewicz
results.brief_description: Docudram about two families in Puerto Rico, one a happy one in which the father and mother love each other and their children, the other one in which there are too many children, no understanding between the parents, and neglected and unhappy children, are contrasted to show the importance of well-adjusted, tolerant, loving parents in the development of happy productive children. Strong comparison made between children and trees, both of which should be planted far enough apart and in a number that can be properly cared for, thus raising questions of birth control.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Sun Dial Films, Puerto Rico. Dept. of Health and Henwar Rodakiewicz

results.title: Loop
results.brief_description: A documentary about Melbourne’s Underground Rail Loop, its effect on the entire metropolitan railway system, and on the future of public transport in Melbourne. Shows the route the loop tracks and tunnels will follow around the city, the sites for the three new underground stations to supplement the present two stations, how passengers will travel from suburban stations when the loop is operating, how the loop is being constructed, and the benefits for train travellers of having five city stations close to shops, theatres and offices. Photographed by Volk Mol, sound by Don Boardman, edited by Geoff Wright, narrated by Michael Pate. Produced for the Melbourne Underground Rail Loop Authority.

results.title: The Magic Trumpet
results.creator_credit: Anim-ad Films, Eltham Films and Dusan Marek
results.brief_description: An experimental film using mainly animated paper cut-outs to tell the story of a magic trumpet which brings fame and fortune to an old tramp. Story script by Tim Burstall, music by Michael Kenny and montage, animation and photography by Dusan Marek.

results.title: [George Robinson Parsons Home Movies: Reel 1]
results.brief_description:
The George Robinson Parsons Home Movie Collection is a collection of home movies originally made on 16mm AGFA film. George Robinson (Robin) Parsons was an amateur filmmaker who made home movies on a Bolex camera during the period 1929 to 1938. The home movies show life in Melbourne and regional Victoria in the 1930s.

This film shows an example of life in Victoria, Australia, just prior to the Second World War. Much of it revolves around members of the Parsons family and friends who are clearly not camera shy. In a number of scenes, you can see individuals playing up to the camera. There is even a staged boxing match on the beach where Robin (George Robinson) Parsons experimented with using special effects.

The film shows several Victorian locations including Melbourne, Dromana, Rosebud Aerodrome, Cape Schanck, Mt Hotham, Mallacoota, Wangarrata and Yallourn. Dromana Beach is featured a few times and appears to be a family favourite for swimming and family gatherings.

This film is rich with fashion of the period, both casual and formal, including two weddings of different periods and golfing attire.

Included in the film is the 1935 centennial celebrations parade showing crowded street with brass bands travelling down Collins Street, including a brief scene of an Aboriginal float. Much of these scenes are taken from the rooftop of Parsons Bros and company building. The company would later form Uncle Toby’s.

The film also includes the Shrine of Remembrance, St Pauls cathedral, Princes Bridge and many other Melbourne landmarks including some buildings and sites that no longer exist.

Of interest are the many forms of transport that are seen throughout which include cars, trams, horses, bicycles, motor bike with side carriage, a canoe, bi planes, fighter planes, a gyrocopter, the Saro A17 Cutty Sark seaplane (only 12 were ever created), transport planes, steamboats, tugboats, a navy ship, locomotives and a Melbourne ferry.

Also of interest is a scene from the 1939 Australian Championship at Kooyong Stadium with John Bromwich and Adrian Quist.

group_siblings.title: [George Robinson Parsons Home Movies: Reel 2]
group_siblings.creator_credit: George Parsons

results.title: [Albert Drayton Home Movies: Reel 8]
results.brief_description:
This film is a continuation from Albert Drayton Home Movies: Reel 7

This film begins with the introduction of the Baining people. The Baining people are the original inhabitants of the Gazelle Peninsula of East New Britain. According to Albert Drayton the people had just been brought out from the mountains as part of the missionary work.

Numerous ceremonies are seen in this film including a wedding, dances, spear throwing and a mock battle.

The later part of the film is the return to Australia briefly visiting Brisbane and Sydney before returning to Melbourne.

Both deck quoits and deck tennis are seen being played on the ship.

There are scenes of the Sydney Harbour bridge, the Sydney Railway station and Town hall.

The film finishes with the Drayton family in Melbourne.

Selected highlights list:
00:00:03:00 – Missionary Grounds and local huts

00:00:31:00 – Footage of the Baining people with women weaving thread and stocking the fire

00:01:08:00 – Performances for the tourists including a marriage ceremony, Tower dance and spear throwing, a ceremonial dance, a mock battle and a victory dance

00:06:05:00 – Mt Drayton with one of the chiefs

00:06:09:00 – Performance with men wearing large decorative head gear supported with string controlled by the women

00:07:23:00 – Baining man with baby

00:07:36:00 – Masks and head pieces being given as a gift to the missionary cruise

00:08:15:00 – Cruise passengers packed into the ship deck on journey back from Papua New Guinea

00:08:48:00 – Cruise Passengers with the ship’s captain and Mr Dennis, the mayor of Northcote, Melbourne

00:09:18:00 – Passengers playing Quoits on the deck of the ship

00:10:11:00 – Views of Sydney Harbour Bridge with Harold Drayton and an Electric Train

00:10:45:00 – Sydney Central Railway Station and Town Hall with street view of traffic officer directing traffic

00:11:34:00 – Mavis, unidentified woman and Mrs Drayton

00:12:36:00 – Drayton family and passengers playing Deck Quoits and Tennis

00:13:26:00 – Albert Drayton and mother unpacking the car at Hampshire Road, Melbourne

00:13:35:00 - Mavis, unknown, Harold, Roy, Albert, unknown, Mrs Drayton (mother)

00:13:45:00 – Members of the Drayton family posing with gifts including Roy, Harold, Albert, Ted Drayton and Mother

00:14:34:00 – Peter (Mavis’s son) crawling to his aeroplane

This film is a continuation from Albert Drayton Home Movies: Reel 7

This film begins with the introduction of the Baining people. The Baining people are the original inhabitants of the Gazelle Peninsula of East New Britain. According to Albert Drayton the people had just been brought out from the mountains as part of the missionary work.

Numerous ceremonies are seen in this film including a wedding, dances, spear throwing and a mock battle.

The later part of the film is the return to Australia briefly visiting Brisbane and Sydney before returning to Melbourne.

Both deck quoits and deck tennis are seen being played on the ship.

There are scenes of the Sydney Harbour bridge, the Sydney Railway station and Town hall.

The film finishes with the Drayton family in Melbourne.

Selected highlights list:
00:00:03:00 – Missionary Grounds and local huts

00:00:31:00 – Footage of the Baining people with women weaving thread and stocking the fire

00:01:08:00 – Performances for the tourists including a marriage ceremony, Tower dance and spear throwing, a ceremonial dance, a mock battle and a victory dance

00:06:05:00 – Mt Drayton with one of the chiefs

00:06:09:00 – Performance with men wearing large decorative head gear supported with string controlled by the women

00:07:23:00 – Baining man with baby

00:07:36:00 – Masks and head pieces being given as a gift to the missionary cruise

00:08:15:00 – Cruise passengers packed into the ship deck on journey back from Papua New Guinea

00:08:48:00 – Cruise Passengers with the ship’s captain and Mr Dennis, the mayor of Northcote, Melbourne

00:09:18:00 – Passengers playing Quoits on the deck of the ship

00:10:11:00 – Views of Sydney Harbour Bridge with Harold Drayton and an Electric Train

00:10:45:00 – Sydney Central Railway Station and Town Hall with street view of traffic officer directing traffic

00:11:34:00 – Mavis, unidentified woman and Mrs Drayton

00:12:36:00 – Drayton family and passengers playing Deck Quoits and Tennis

00:13:26:00 – Albert Drayton and mother unpacking the car at Hampshire Road, Melbourne

00:13:35:00 - Mavis, unknown, Harold, Roy, Albert, unknown, Mrs Drayton (mother)

00:13:45:00 – Members of the Drayton family posing with gifts including Roy, Harold, Albert, Ted Drayton and Mother

00:14:34:00 – Peter (Mavis’s son) crawling to his aeroplane
